1569269870_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
>Your landlord, city or zoning officer tells you to remove it. 

You don't even own the property and want to replace the lawn with moss?  You need the owner's permission at the very least for that.  If the city is complaining then you're probably screwed, but can try to fight it.  Maybe a judge will agree with you.

1570025997_19AdL7EWPFiXiep63Ahacx21EibX5.body: Yes, usually.  Lots of times we aren't  doing anything anyone cares about monitoring.  Lots of times we log into sites who know exactly who we are.  Sometimes we'd prefer they know about where we are coming from (e.g. searching for a restaurant) so they can give us better results.

1574560433_1Gvs3AKBY5YjUMPchHuoQuAYnWApB.body:
I'm a bit interested in this too and it does seem seem like their has been a lot of Holocaust exaggerations and sketchy claims taken at face value while all skepticism is met with ad hominem attacks against the skeptic.  

I don't necessarily doubt that there was a mass slaughter of Jews by Nazis in some shape and form, but the lies should be called out, context given, the Nazi point-of-view represented.  The way the Nazis and Hitler are talked about by the establishment is as one-sided as the way they talk about Trump.  I've read enough to know that Hitler had a lot of good points in the government he was trying to (and did for awhile) establish.  Very pro-family, anti-degeneracy, etc.

Perhaps the best way to tackle this would be just to take a list of Holocaust claims and evaluate them one by one.
